title: Drug-driving teen who killed two men in horror crash faces new police probe
text:
Max Coopey, then 17, gave ‘no comment’ answers in interviews to police after he was arrested over the deaths of workmates outside the Royal Berkshire Hotel, Ascot

The words of a drug-driving teenager who escaped jail despite mowing down two men are being reviewed by police – after he gave his first account of the offence at an inquest into their deaths.

Police officer’s son Max Coopey, then 17, gave ‘no comment’ answers in interviews to police after he was arrested over the deaths of workmates John Shackley and Jason Imi in August last year, just two months after passing his driving test.

His silence, and a lack of witnesses to the late-night crash outside the hotel where the men were staying, left police reliant on a collision investigation report.

Thames Valley Police concluded Coopey’s driving of his father’s £35,000 Audi A5 was not dangerous, but did not consult the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS). As a result, Coopey, who had a string of previous convictions, faced a drug-driving charge, rather than death by dangerous or careless driving which carry jail terms of 14 years and five years respectively.

Yesterday, as the families of Mr Shackley, 61, from Milton Keynes, and Mr Imi, 48, from Twickenham, south-west London, called on police to reopen the case, it emerged that officers were reviewing statements Coopey gave at the inquest. It raises the prospect of Coopey, who was given 100 hours of community service at Reading Youth Court and banned from the road for two years over the fatal crash, potentially being re-arrested and charged again.

Victim: John Shackley, 61, from Milton Keynes, was killed in August last year. His family are calling on police to reopen the case

Victim: Jason Imi, 48, from Twickenham, south-west London, pictured with his wife Sarah

Coopey (pictured), who admitted smoking cannabis before the crash, said: ‘I first braked when they were on the pavement because they are looking out on the road as if they are going to cross'

Mr Shackley’s daughter Danielle, 31, said: ‘Coopey is basically sat there laughing at us. We cannot rest and we cannot grieve. We are not getting any justice and we are not being treated properly. How can you get behind the wheel of a car while you are high on drugs, kill two people and not go to prison?’

Family lawyers say Coopey’s account of the crash at Sunninghill, Berkshire, suggests he may have been speeding, which should have led to the CPS to consider charging him with causing death by dangerous driving. They believe the police investigation was ‘flawed’ and are ‘baffled’ why officers did not submit a file of evidence to the CPS. Coopey, now 18, lives in a £1 million house in Ascot, with his parents, Russel, a sergeant in the Met, and Catherine Coopey, who until last year was a schools liaison officer in the same force.

He broke his silence over the fatal incident outside the Royal Berkshire Hotel at an inquest on July 8. Coopey, who admitted smoking cannabis before the crash, said: ‘I first braked when they were on the pavement because they are looking out on the road as if they are going to cross.’

Nicholas Hinchliffe QC, for the families, said a tyre mark on the road matching the tread of the Audi showed Coopey had applied the brakes only at the point of impact, despite having at least two seconds to react.

Thames Valley Police said: ‘A review of the statements by Max Coopey ... is being undertaken.’
description: The words of drug-driver Max Coopey, 18, are being reviewed by police after he gave his first account of the offence at the inquests over two deaths. He broke his silence over incident in Ascot, Berkshire.
authors: Andy Dolan For The Daily Mail
